subject: RE: [junit] Re: about teardown
msgSnippet: Hello, Correct me if I m wrong, but you really only want to call  [ super.setUp() ] If you have extended a testcase the you have written? Example: public class
messageBody:
Hello,

Correct me if I'm wrong, but you really only want to call [
super.setUp() ]
If you have extended a testcase the you have written?

Example:

public class testCaseB extends testCaseA {

void setUp() { super.setup(); /** the rest of setup */}
}

As opposed to:
In this case, I believe that the whole point of overriding setup() is to
avoid the base class's [TestCase] implementation.

public class testCaseA extends TestCase {

void setup() { /** whatever you want to setup, no call to super */
}

This is how I understood this anyways, but then again, I am but a simple
caveman. =))

--Ryan

- reset global state to the state before the test:
Example:
Object oldTool;
protected void setUp() throws Exception {
super.setUp();
oldTool = Toolbox.getTool("ThreadFactory");
Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",new TestThreadFactory());
}

protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",oldTool);
}


What are others doing in their tearDowns?

Cheers,

Arnd.

BTW: Never forget to call the super setUp and tearDown!
